Just wanted to say... I really enjoy Dragon Ball Gekishin Squadra, but the character unlock system is honestly a bit ridiculous. If you're already high level, it feels like there's no real way to get the new characters without spending gems‚Ä¶ and you barely get 15 gems a week. That makes future updates feel kind of locked off unless you pay.

On the other hand, I actually like that there's no chat. It avoids all the flaming, crying, and overreactions that ruin a lot of other games. People sometimes make "bold decisions" which can be good,but stuff like rushing into the God of Destruction zone before it‚Äôs even open by Zeno? Yeah, that‚Äôs trolling. And I don't think most players even realize the report button exists after a match. Use it. Hopefully they vanish from the queue.

Trolls showing up even in A or S rank is rough, but the game is still fun. It‚Äôs like a Dragon Ball version of Dota, and I wish they added more cards or systems to customize builds - that‚Äôs something Dragon Ball usually shines at.

It's still a MOBA and has some skill gap, but most of the time you just sit, relax and enjoy the animations and the FEELING of really playing as a DB character with obliterating powers!

Sadly the game has it's bugs and connectivity issues, but they are not really a game breaking problem, since I only experienced it a very few times, I hope they fix them soon tho. My only real issue are those freakin' in-game announcements that take all over the screen, they are distracting and cover almost everything, I would like an option to make them less-intrusive or just turn them off.

I encourage everyone to try it and support the game if you like it, since I can see it was made with love.

I'm not into MOBAs. I never got into League of Legends, never clicked in me. I played Heroes of the Storm with a friend for a while, mostly for the Overwatch heroes, but I quit after a while because it was super slow and laggy. Aside from those heroes, I wasn't interested in any of the others. Sorry, I was never a Blizzard fan, although I did play quite a bit of WoW in Horde mode for a few years.

What I like about Dragon Ball Gekishin Squadra is that it's fast-paced, and as Abridge Vegeta would say, "power levels are bull***t," and everything goes to hell when the characters reach levels 10 to 15. I'm very happy with the character roster, and the possibilities are enormous.

Artistically, it's beautiful. I love how they captured every little detail of Dragon Ball lore, and the gameplay, so similar to an anime, really makes you believe this could have been something like the Tournament of Power, with some kind of game-hour encounter with Zen'o Sama and the anime-style scenes and interactions.

I like the Assist and Helper systems, but I feel the Card system makes a huge difference if you choose the wrong one.

Now, the matchmaking is a real problem because the Steam player base is getting smaller and smaller, and it's very difficult to find matches, especially for unranked games, which have fun game modes that nobody plays. It's gotten to the point where even the achievement for playing 5 Sub-Rule Battles has become one of the hardest to get.

While I don't have a problem with unlocking heroes because I like to play with specific characters, I do notice the problem for someone more competitive or interested in playing the latest characters; for them, unlocking heroes becomes impossible without spending money. As a game designer with 19 years of experience in MMORPGs, I've noticed problems with the balance of the soft currency, which is scarce (although there were some changes in Season 2 to increase it). 

The core is that it's a very Asian-Like mmo, heavily focused on the old-school grinding of 20 years ago, and in the era of instant rewards, that kind of balance and dynamics aren't popular nowadays with people who have so little time. 

I understand that the idea is for players to grind two types of currency by playing with Heroes, and thus progress to unlock heroes. I saw the rebalances that added some of the newest ones like Toppo to unlock for free, but the progression is still so slow, even for a player who dedicates many hours, that I simply think it's demotivating the community. 

While it doesn't affect me personally heroes wise, I do notice how it's slowly shrinking the community and that indeed affects me direclty.

I wish the game wouldn't shut down, but unless mobile keeps it going, I don't see much of a future for it on PC. 

Even so, I recommend it because the essence of the game goes beyond its micro-economy balance. It's a good tribute, and I like how dynamic and fast-paced it is, the art direction, and the unlockables, but it needs more currency balance re work and actions, boost other game modes too, or it will close.

Gekishin Squadra is‚Ä¶ certainly a game released this year.
I played it. I can confirm that playing occurred. Truly, gaming has never been so game.

From the moment I booted it up, I thought, ‚ÄúWow. They really did press ‚Äòrelease‚Äô on this.‚Äù The graphics? They exist. The sound? Audible. The gameplay? Oh, it sure is doing something in there.

The story had me absolutely speechless mostly because I had no idea what was happening, but silence is still a reaction, and reactions are good, right? The characters are so memorable that I remember that they were, in fact, characters. Somewhere. Probably.

Combat feels like someone whispered ‚Äúinnovation‚Äù into a blender and hit pur√©e. It‚Äôs not bad it‚Äôs just aggressively there, like a coworker who keeps showing you pictures of their cat even though you didn‚Äôt ask.

My favorite part was when the game‚Ä¶ happened. You‚Äôll know the part. Trust me. You can‚Äôt miss it. I tried.

Overall, Gekishin Squadra is the most Gekishin Squadra-looking Gekishin Squadra to ever Gekishin Squadra. A monument to this year's commitment to releasing video games, sometimes even on purpose.

10/10 ‚Äî would say "yup, that‚Äôs a game" again.

Most important thing first:
[b] Yes, the game is fun. [/b]

Like any game, this one has its issues, but maybe they go a bit beyond the usual. The game has shaken players‚Äô trust, especially those worried about how hard it is to unlock every playable character without paying. Season 2 brought changes, it‚Äôs far from perfect, but it‚Äôs definitely better.

If you‚Äôre thinking about trying it because you want a fast-paced MOBA and you enjoy Dragon Ball, then I don‚Äôt see why you shouldn‚Äôt give it a shot. The mechanics and overall gameplay loop are fun.
The biggest gameplay problem right now is the heavy use of bots. For a multiplayer game, it fails to offer a healthy amount of real matches, which leaves the community frustrated and unsure about trusting any teammate.

Overall, it‚Äôs a good game to chill, not take too seriously, and have some fun MOBA sessions.

However, I think the main problem with the game is how you unlock the newest characters (excluding launch characters). Theres two ways to unlock them. Buy them from the shop for 6$ or wait until NEXT SEASON to unlock them for free. By then, the op new character (ss3 goku) will get nerfed and become unusable. In a nutshell, PLEASE TOSHI MAKE IT SO WHERE U CAN GET CHARACTERS FOR FREE at least not until the next season after they launch.

very fun and very addictive, but has some issues:

1 - the player base is toxic: dude its a fucking moba with dragon ball fans of course its gonna be toxic

2 - some characters are p2w: while the paid characters (mainly toppo) have solid counters, it still feels somewhat scummy to lock them behind a forced paywall to people who cant afford them. this can be resolved by putting the newer characters in the free trial rotation, or eventually increase the star road levels to enable them being unlocked, while still very grindy as the star system is a lil ass, it makes up for it as the game is somewhat enjoying and fun to play.
and while this game has cons, it does have its pros
the game is very balanced, while most characters (even the paid ones) seem like fun options, the game comes with a diverse cast that can mold into your play style, and even mold around a teams play style (except bojack he sucks ass lmao)
the only form of gacha is entirely cosmetic, providing no ample advantage for someone who wasted 300 dollars (me) for an intro they probably didnt get. while still asking for money (albeit in a slight greedy sense) the game prefers you to get one time, permanent game play additions, instead of promoting gambling to get certain characters.

Just gonna list out points that annoy me about this game (I was S rank in every role btw so i played the game enough):

Connection issues at launch all the way to halfway through season 1 (which is the second ranked season). This is purely due to poor optimization and bad servers. 

Greedy F2P monetization model that barely rewards you with premium currency (10 gems a week when a single new character costs 250, i earned 165 gems total playing since launch including events.)

Star collection progression system actively punishes long term players from playing the game, if you were playing since launch with the current changes you basically overpaid for every single hero you unlocked which at a minimum is at least 250 gems in value (which is only counting the change at level 31 where you can now unlock season 1 characters)

They changed it very recently due to backlash but it was intended by the devs that you would never be able to unlock a newly released character through the star collection system only the previous season's characters.

Hero levelling costs are exponential and you earn a minimal amount of zeni (which is the standard non-premium currency you use in games to upgrade stuff) which means the longer you play the harder it is to earn levels in the star collection, levels 1-109 is the same as level 109-119.

New characters feel extremely overtuned and SSJ4 vegeta seems like a massive overreaction to SSJ3 goku and shows how the devs will be making new characters going forward. Oh what a coincidence they nerfed season 1 characters right as season 2 came out.

Every season i've played this game the devs have found innovative new ways to make the game actively worse for F2P players and active players (which makes no sense in a live service game)

I do find the game fun to a certain point, however the game will not succeed if the devs continue to have a casual mindset to the game, team games like mobas need to have competitivenes in mind as the standard. Any other genre is fine for the usual dragon ball casual fun but that development process will end up killing this game specifically due to payed players having the best characters in the game without letting free players get them as soon as they come out. Gekishin Squadra has solid gameplay mechanics and can be genuinely fun... when matchmaking works. Unfortunately, that‚Äôs rare.

Ranked solo queue is a mess. One match you‚Äôre teamed with competent players, the next you‚Äôre stuck with teammates who ignore objectives, don‚Äôt understand their roles, or rage after a single misplay. Meanwhile, the enemy team feels like a coordinated squad with perfect target focus and map awareness.

Add in AFKers, ping spammers, and trolls who throw games over petty drama, and it becomes a frustrating grind. The reward system doesn‚Äôt justify the effort, making it hard to stay motivated.

To make matters worse, pay-to-win mechanics are deeply embedded. Sure, you can grind gems to unlock characters, but the process is painfully slow and time-gated. Events that award gems are limited, and realistically, you can expect to unlock a new Z-tier character maybe once a year as a free-to-play player. Meanwhile, premium characters like SSJ3 Goku are blatantly overpowered, dominating the meta and making competitive progression feel hopeless unless you pay up.

Until proper matchmaking is implemented, solo queue toxicity is addressed, and the monetization model is rebalanced, I can‚Äôt recommend this game in good faith.

This is one of those games that makes me wish steam review has a "Neutral" option as I'm extremely mixed about it.

-The goods: 
+The graphic is decent but the character models are very pretty, animations are crispy and very satisfying to watch.
+As a solo-queue player the gameplay at it's core is fun, as it is a very VERY simplified version of the MOBA genre even without comparing it to the big ones like League or Dota or smaller ones like Arena of Valor or Mobile Legends.
+To continue with the point above, matches are fast and I really enjoy them being like this instead them being able to last from 15 minutes to hours like alot of MOBAs.

-The horrible horrible parts:
+To start it off, the game is so grindy for absolutely no reason as if the devs are scared of Bandai executing them for giving us more zeni and gems. The star system even with the recent changes to make paid characters f2p still sucks, the shortage of zeni only adds to the problem, it feels as if the system is there to not only punish f2p players but also people who have been playing this game for a long time. It needs to be changed for the sake of both players and the game itself.
+Ranked matches are filled with bots that do nothing but feed kills to the enemy team, there're times I would be in a team with 3 bots fighting against 4 humans. I don't get why they thought this was a good idea in the first place, it just makes the game unfair especially when you're playing as a tank or a support character since even if you are at an advantage, it's nigh impossible to win against actual humans when the bots don't even know what to do aside from dying. Simple solution is to just fully remove them, I know people are willing to wait longer if it means they have a chance of getting human teammates.
+Connection issues as well as crashes started happening alot more after season 2 update and haven't been fixed yet, your game can crash multiple times during a match for no reason and it's very frustrating trying to play the game recently with this connection issue.

The game has alot to improve and I really hope the devs listen more to the community because if things continue the same way it might not even last as long as Dragon Ball the Breakers or hell even Sparking Zero.
Edit: Use the official Gekishin discord server and give them your feedbacks there, they DO hear us.

Really fun but ranked is filled with bots, and these bots are TERRIBLE. The bots prioritise the wrong objectives at the wrong times, only use their skills to get into fights and never to run away, and push into fights until they're at a quarter of their health, feeding constantly. It's to the point where if you aren't high in the ranks you'll be playing with 2 or more bots on your team. Climbing rank in anything other then the higher ranks isn't about skill but choosing the characters and builds to take the most advantage of the feeding bots before your bots feed them in turn. The only modes where you can be guaranteed to play with a full team of real players against a full team of real players are the party game modes that cycle every 4 days because they couldn't be bothered to code the AI for them.

As for the other flaws, the game is a free to play mobile game so the monetization and progression are pretty much what you'd expect. You can get a good amount of the roster for free early on (for perspective, I have 40 hours as of writing this and have 16 characters unlocked) but after the honey moon period it slows drastically. If you're waiting for any particular character that isn't already in the f2p roster you might as well wait until they're added to play, since progressing too early means you'll have a way harder time actually unlocking them. Cosmetics are gacha and shop exclusive and the free pulls are very limited so if you care about cosmetics you'll need to gamble for them or spend money on the handful in the shop.

The game is also super casual focused which I don't mind much but it means that even ranked involves party game style match events called "Divine Draws" which can vary from minor gameplay changes to ridiculous gameplay defining mechanic additions. There's also a lot of players who are new to moba's and don't know what they're doing, not big issues for me but I know more diehard competitive minded players will find these frustrating.

It's fun but it's clear what angle they're going for so if you don't like what you see you're probably not going to enjoy it.

The game is good per se, but the system around it suffers from one too many problems... because of this, the game becomes frustrating and borderline anti-fun.

1) Playing in comp and solo players:
There is no in-game way to show you're in a comp with a friend (like a little sticker next to your name for example), meaning that sometimes, a third player will want to go in the same lane as you and your friend, and will absolutely not want to move, thinking "I was there first" when you just want to play with your friend on the same lane as a DPS and a Tank for example. You're bound to mass spam the same emote with your friend to try and make him understand you're with your friend so that he can leave. It becomes an ego battle for this third player and because of that, he will most likely not go away.

2) Innactivity and forfeiting: 
The game doesn't compensate you for losing due to innactive teammates, which gets increasingly frustrating because some players will just call a vote to forfeit the game as soon as they think the game is lost, when in general, it is very much salvageable. If you decide not to forfeit because you still WANNA PLAY THE GAME, those petty players will just stop being useful, purposefully losing the game so that you can vote to forfeit next time. It is very annoying because it happens more the higher ranks you get, and the game never compensate for those. I'm sure it is possible to make it detectable by the game when someone sells on purpose. Those types of players are what massively kills the game because there is no way to account for their behavior and they quite literally control the flow of the game. People, if you act this way, please, just stop playing the game, as you are seemingly too easy to trigger. You are an active liability for us players who want to play till the end.

3) lack of feedback when reporting:
This ties in to this next problem. When you report people for their behavior, you don't have any feedback from the game whether they get punished or not. You also don't know if it prevents or lowers the chance you will get paired with them in future matches. All this makes the player feels like they're screaming into the void. It feels useless. Game to player feedback is one if not the most important aspect that can make or break the fun of the game.

4) The dreaded golden Cell Jr divine card:
Each match, two "rules" will be randomly selected to spice up the game. They generally are interesting as it makes you play differently and strategize in quite unique ways. But amongst those rules there is one that everyone hates. The golden Cell Jrs. When this rule is selected, golden cell jrs will randomly spawn during the match. Their location and number are quite random. They can appear near your team's territory or your enemies' or both at the same time. Upon killing them, you instantly get enough XP to level up, giving you the occasion to level up your skills at the same time. And this is where it goes wrong. They tend to appear after the first fight happened in the middle of the arena, which means that the winning side, which already got exp from winning their battle, also gets to kill the Cell Jr and level up once more. Because of the travel time from spawn to middle, the winning team has enough time to farm cpus in mid.

This situation happens EVERYTIME this rule is applied. And because of that, right at the start of the match a team can be 2 or even 3 levels ahead of you, virtually making it impossible to come back. Since you also upgrade skills by levelling up, you end up having way more firepower than your enemies, while also having more HP and attack stats. It becomes one sided very fast, right at the beginning. It kills the fun for everyone, this rule needs to be removed...

5) Unfortunately pay to win:
Some Characters cannot be unlocked without paying real money, effectively locking them away from players who do not want to spend money in an online game. The problem is that those characters are way too strong to incentivize you to pay to unlock and play them. the biggest problem is Goku SSJ3. He has the ability to teleport to a teammate OR an enemy if he's visible on the map, and can instantly fire a charged kamehameha. If you didn't guess it by now, the kamehameha is extremely powerful, able to kill you at full HP if leveled up enough times. And if it wasn't enough, he can adjust the angle of the beam while firing, which means if you get hit by it, you can most likely not even avoid taking further damage as the opponent just has to follow your character. Because of that, you can't properly pick fights that you can win because at any moment, goku could just instantly teleport to you to kill you, effectively transforming a 1v1 into a 2v1 or a 2v2 into a 3v2. The skill is so powerful that in a 4v4 this skill can kill an entire team if they're stacked together. His ultimate attack, dragon fist, is also extremely powerful, has a wide range, and fires too fast to react to in most cases.

Anyway, they know he is way too strong, but they don't care, because they want you to spend money to buy him. he will be nerfed next season when he gets available to free to play players I'm sure, but he will get replaced by a new pay to win character for the new season that you can't unlock without money.

6) The lack of progression:
At first, you'll unlock characters like crazy, even upgrade their little figures which makes you progress on the general star level of the game. But when you finish doing all the season missions the game gives you, there is actually no way to keep getting enough Zeni to further upgrade character figures. And this prevents you from levelling up your star level, which in turn, prevents you from unlocking new characters. Your progression is quite literally finite and you can't progress any further until the game says otherwise.

All this makes for a terribly unfun context when you want to have fun with friends.
It's very sad because otherwise, the game is fun, the characters are enjoyable to play, and quite diverse...

Game is alright but needs more features to punish/limit AFK players. Stomps are fairly common, putting you into games against coordinated teams vs your team of randoms. Account creation is also initially confusing. For example, if you first download on mobile you must first create an ingame account then you can go back and link it to a Bandai ID. Then if you go to Steam and try the same method to link to the same ID, it instead locks you into the account you just created and you cannot link to the first account created, preventing any form of cross-playing/saving. On mobile you can delete your account and start over, while there is 0 form of recourse on Steam besides from creating a second steam account to correctly link IDs to. It may be user error but there is zero reason steam accounts must be permanently linked while other platforms can freely delete their data.

This game is actually really bad. It has pay to win characters in a highly competitive Moba game, and the company behind it clearly has profit incentives, as they broke their own rules for the tournament they are running, only so that you can make a party with exclusively paid characters.

After the season was over, as we predicted day one, the overpowered, p2w characters were nerfed, and a reasonable way to obtain them in game was added, only to spit in the face of players even more.

Don't spend a cent in this game. Honestly, we shouldn't even play it, but at this point I'm too invested in the tournament to just quit. But after that? I don't think I'll be touching this game again.

As of season 2, a way to acquire the paid characters was added, and a total disregard was given to players that had already achieved the level required to achieve that. 

As if all of that was not enough, some of the mechanics in the game are actively bad. You cannot choose when to use your abilities to deal damage to the tower, or when to cast it at enemies, causing the under tower to be a terrible position to fight from even when you are at an advantage in level and positioning to your enemy. Requiring you to skirt around the objective to fight, which is disadvantageous to melee characters, as well as just being a *terrible* mechanic all around, it barely works, and is ping dependant.

Less of a mechanic, more of a pet peeve, why is the random option dependant on party order???? I want to click random on my party and be placed on a random role lmao. If you queue random with 4 friends, all of you will always land the exact same roles until the party is disassembled and reassembled. 

Visibility is also a problem in big teamfights. It is very hard to tell what's going on. 

This is a shame of a game.

What do I like about this game? Uh... I like that matches are short, Fighting other players is pretty fun, but I give more credit to being here early than to the game being awesome. It is also cross compatible with cellphones, which means there's lots of children playing. 

Our most fun matches, as a party of four, is to absolutely ruin the day of someone who paid upwards of 50R$ to buy a pay to win character because they have zero game sense and die in any teamfight, only able to have a chance because they have a broken ass hero.
